data.title: FamilyTreeDNA
data.meta_description: Discover your DNA story and unlock the secrets of your ancestry and genealogy with our autosomal DNA, Y-DNA, and mtDNA tests.
data.text:
Results and Ancestor Lists

Results are listed numerically by Groups as they appear on the Y-DNA Results charts (Select "DNA Results" from the choices on the left side of the Activity Feed page.). Two versions of the generated charts are provided by FTDNA—Classic and Colorized. For the kits that have matches and have been assigned to a group, the colorized chart is most helpful as it shows the “mutations” or differences from what is currently assigned as the “modal” value for each of the markers. For those kits which are still without matches in either the No Group or the UK unmatched kits, the Classic chart is less confusing.

Individual ancestries are being made available for research by the person testing or their family researcher and cannot be guaranteed for accuracy by the Turner DNA project. They are suggested as guidelines to identify the branch of Turners tested rather than to be used for specific date documentation. All data should be independently confirmed. You are encouraged to find a male Turner of your own line to test to confirm that you do indeed match a specific line. There have been surprises--whether as a result of wrong research or previously unsuspected non-paternity events--so don't just assume that your line will match a posted line.

Kits that were originally tested in the National Geographic Society’s Genographic Project are preceded with an “N” and will be at the end of each groups’ kits. Kits that begin with "B" are people who originally tested with Ancestry.com or 23andMe and transferred their results to our Turner DNA Project. All kits that we originally called “No Group” are now listed near the bottom after all other groups. A separate group, also at the bottom, has been created for United Kingdom lines or ones with more recent known UK roots which still do not have matches. At the very end will be a category called “Ungrouped” where new results reported out of the lab automatically go until they are analyzed to see if they have matches close enough to be included in one of the other groups or will go into our No Group. We will normally move these kits into a group as soon as we can see if they clearly match another group.

Please use your browser’s search find feature to locate a kit number. No information on testees or contact information is allowed under requirements of the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in effect as of May 25, 2018.

Group 1 – Salmon

This group is believed to originate with a William Turner born about 1645 in who married a mythical Mary McLemore. They supposedly came to the American colonies to escape religious persecution and major branches of it settled on the Eastern Shore of MD in and Somerset Co. MD area. The information on this family originally appeared in records of the Philadelphia Historical Society but no one seems to be able to actually replicate the information today. One researcher of the group believes he found some trace of a figure Guilliame Turner who may fit the description and time period. One of the major branches of this group can be traced from Worcester and Somerset Co. MD with family members who served in the Revolution in MD and then migrated about 1791 to Hancock Co. GA. The exact connection of the other branches is not clear. A large group of Turners with matching DNA settled on the upper border of SC in what was first Spartanburg Co. SC and just across the border in NC in an area that was at times Anson, Tryon, Mecklenburg and then Rutherford Co. NC area. It is believed that they likely came from MD and or PA to Onslow Co. NC then moved into the interior area that was this area by 1770.

Group 5 - Teal

Researchers of this group of Turners, who DNA has shown are related, believe that some of them are likely descended from a group of Turner families that were involved in three "Leases for three lives" in Prince William Co. VA in 1747. The oldest men of these three leases were men named William Turner, James Turner and Edward Turner. It includes a well known Turner family-- James Turner who married Karenhappuch Norman. It also includes some families that were in the Northeast corner of TN and in the Southeast corner of KY--one of which includes the famed "Devil Jim Turner."
